title: Ticket #4088: Use of select() overrunning bit array bounds
description:
In a couple spots of Condor, we're calling select() with single fd_sets. This will corrupt memory on unix if any of the fds being selected on have values greater than 1023. We have the Selector class in the util lib to handle high-numbered fds safely. It should be used in these cases.

Calls to select() with fd_sets happen in the following locations:

  • src/condor_ckpt/file_state.cpp: CondorFileTable::select() Do we want and need to touch the checkpointing code?

  • src/condor_ckpt_server/server2.cpp: Server::Execute() Always uses a handful of fds that are created at startup. Should not be a problem, but can use Selector class.

  • src/condor_procd/named_pipe_reader.unix.cpp: NamedPipeReader::read_data(), NamedPipeReader::poll() Should use Selector class.

  • src/condor_procd/named_pipe_writer.unix.cpp: NamedPipeWriter::write_data() Should use Selector class.

  • src/condor_shadow.std/shadow.cpp: HandleSyscalls() Selects on RSC_SOCK and CLIENT_LOG. These seem to be defined and set in the syscall lib.

  • src/condor_syscall_lib/*: Here there be dragons!

We have observed this bug cause a heavily-loaded schedd to crash while trying to talk to the procd when creating a starter for a local universe job.
remarks:
This will also fix #4009
